net.varkhan.base.containers.array
Class CharArrays

java.lang.Object
  net.varkhan.base.containers.array.CharArrays

public class CharArrays
extends java.lang.Object

Static char arrays manipulation utilities.

Utilities for manipulating arrays of chars and character sequences.

Method Detail

equals

public static boolean equals(char[] array1,
                             char[] array2)
Indicates whether two char arrays are equal.

Parameters:
array1 - the first array
array2 - the second array
Returns:
true iff the arrays are either both null or have the same number of elements, and the values of elements in the same positions are equal

equals

public static boolean equals(java.lang.CharSequence seq1,
                             java.lang.CharSequence seq2)
Indicates whether two CharSequence are equal.

Parameters:
seq1 - the first array
seq2 - the second array
Returns:
true iff the CharSequences are either both null or have the same number of characters, and the same characters in the same positions

indexOf

public static int indexOf(char item,
                          char... array)
Returns the position of the first occurrence of a value inside an array.

Parameters:
item - the value to search for
array - the array to search
Returns:
-1 if item was not found in array, the position of the first element of the array equal to item

indexOf

public static int indexOf(char[] array,
                          int pos,
                          char[] sub)
Returns the position of the first occurrence of an array as a subsequence of an other array.

Parameters:
array - the array
pos - the starting point in the array
sub - the subsequence to find
Returns:
the smallest index idx greater than pos such that the elements of array starting at idx are exactly those of sub (-1 is returned if sub is not a subsequence of array)

searchInc

public static int searchInc(char[] ary,
                            int inf,
                            int sup,
                            char key)
Finds an object in a sorted array, in ascending order.

Parameters:
ary - the sorted array
inf - the minimum index
sup - the maximum index
key - the value to search for
Returns:
the key position in the array, or -(inspos+1), where inspos is the index of the first value in the array bigger than key

inf - the minimum index
sup - the maximum index
key - the value to search for
Returns:
the key position in the array, or -(inspos+1), where inspos is the index of the first value in the array bigger than key

unionInc

public static char[] unionInc(char[] ary1,
                              int beg1,
                              int len1,
                              char[] ary2,
                              int beg2,
                              int len2)
Computes the union of segments in two sorted arrays, in ascending order.

Parameters:
ary1 - the first sorted array
beg1 - the start position of the first segment
len1 - the length of the first segment
ary2 - the second sorted array
beg2 - the start position of the second segment
len2 - the length of the second segment
Returns:
the union of the two segments, with duplicates removed

Returns:

subarray

public static char[] subarray(char[] array,
                              int beg,
                              int end)
Returns a segment of an array.

Parameters:
array - the source array
beg - the begining position of the segment, inclusive
end - the ending position of the segment, exclusive
Returns:
an array of chars, of length end-beg, and containing all the elements between positions beg, inclusive, and end, exclusive, of the original array

tr

public static int tr(char[] str,
                     int pos,
                     int len,
                     char[] pat,
                     char[] rep)
Transliterates (replaces single characters in) a segment of a char array.

Characters that are contained in the matching set are counted, and replaced by the character at the same position in the replacement set as the matched character in the matching set. Duplicate characters in the matching set are ignored, and only the first occurrence is taken into account. If the replacement set is shorter than the matching set, the remaining matched characters are counted, but remain unchanged. If the replacement set is longer, the remaining characters are ignored.

Parameters:
str - a char array containing the segment
pos - the position of the first character of the segment
len - the length of (number of characters in) the segment
pat - the matching character set (the set of characters to replace)
rep - the replacement character set (the characters to replace with)
Returns:
the number of characters that have been matched in the segment

tr

public static int tr(char[] str,
                     char[] pat,
                     char[] rep)
Transliterates (replaces single characters in) a char array.

Characters that are contained in the matching set are counted, and replaced by the character at the same position in the replacement set as the matched character in the matching set. Duplicate characters in the matching set are ignored, and only the first occurrence is taken into account. If the replacement set is shorter than the matching set, the remaining matched characters are counted, but remain unchanged. If the replacement set is longer, the remaining characters are ignored.

Parameters:
str - a char array
pat - the matching character set (the set of characters to replace)
rep - the replacement character set (the characters to replace with)
Returns:
the number of characters that have been matched in the segment

tr

public static java.lang.CharSequence tr(java.lang.CharSequence str,
                                        char[] pat,
                                        char[] rep)
Transliterates (replaces single characters in) a CharSequence.

Characters that are contained in the matching set are counted, and replaced by the character at the same position in the replacement set as the matched character in the matching set. Duplicate characters in the matching set are ignored, and only the first occurrence is taken into account. If the replacement set is shorter than the matching set, the remaining matched characters are counted, but remain unchanged. If the replacement set is longer, the remaining characters are ignored.

Parameters:
str - a CharSequence
pat - the matching character set (the set of characters to replace)
rep - the replacement character set (the characters to replace with)
Returns:
a new CharSequence with the replaced characters

tr

public static java.lang.String tr(java.lang.String sep,
                                  char[] pat,
                                  char[] rep)
Transliterates (replaces single characters in) a String.

Characters that are contained in the matching set are counted, and replaced by the character at the same position in the replacement set as the matched character in the matching set. Duplicate characters in the matching set are ignored, and only the first occurrence is taken into account. If the replacement set is shorter than the matching set, the remaining matched characters are counted, but remain unchanged. If the replacement set is longer, the remaining characters are ignored.

Parameters:
sep - a String
pat - the matching character set (the set of characters to replace)
rep - the replacement character set (the characters to replace with)
Returns:
a new String with the replaced characters

repl

public static java.lang.StringBuilder repl(java.lang.StringBuilder buf,
                                           java.lang.CharSequence str,
                                           char pat,
                                           java.lang.CharSequence rep)
Replace a character by a CharSequence.

Appends each character of the source sequence to the buffer, except for segments that match the pattern, for which the replacement is appended instead.

Parameters:
buf - the buffer to append the result to
str - the source CharSequence
pat - the character to replace
rep - the CharSequence to replace matches with
Returns:
the original buffer, for chaining purposes

repl

public static <A extends java.lang.Appendable> A repl(A buf,
                                                      java.lang.CharSequence str,
                                                      char pat,
                                                      java.lang.CharSequence rep)
                                           throws java.io.IOException
Replace a character by a CharSequence.

Appends each character of the source sequence to the buffer, except for segments that match the pattern, for which the replacement is appended instead.

Parameters:
buf - the buffer to append the result to
str - the source CharSequence
pat - the character to replace
rep - the CharSequence to replace matches with
Returns:
the original buffer, for chaining purposes
Throws:
java.io.IOException - if the output buffer raises this exception on append()

Replace a subsequence by an other in a segment of a character array.

Appends each character of the source segment to the buffer, except for segments that match the pattern, for which the replacement is appended instead.

Parameters:
buf - the buffer to append the result to
str - the source character array
pos - the position of the segment in the array
len - the length of the segment
pat - the subsequence to replace in the segment
rep - the subsequence to replace matches with
Returns:
the original buffer, for chaining purposes

repl

public static java.lang.StringBuilder repl(java.lang.StringBuilder buf,
                                           java.lang.CharSequence str,
                                           java.lang.CharSequence[] pat,
                                           java.lang.CharSequence[] rep)
Replace multiple subsequences in a CharSequence.

Appends each character of the source sequence to the buffer, except for segments that match one of the pattern, for which the sequence at the same position in the replacement array is appended instead.

Parameters:
buf - the buffer to append the result to
str - the source CharSequence
pat - the array of CharSequence to replace in the source
rep - the array of CharSequence to replace corresponding matches with
Returns:
the original buffer, for chaining purposes

public static <A extends java.lang.Appendable> A repl(A buf,
                                                      java.lang.CharSequence str,
                                                      java.lang.CharSequence[] pat,
                                                      java.lang.CharSequence[] rep)
                                           throws java.io.IOException
Replace multiple subsequences in a CharSequence.

Appends each character of the source sequence to the buffer, except for segments that match one of the pattern, for which the sequence at the same position in the replacement array is appended instead.

Parameters:
buf - the buffer to append the result to
str - the source CharSequence
pat - the array of CharSequence to replace in the source
rep - the array of CharSequence to replace corresponding matches with
Returns:
the original buffer, for chaining purposes
Throws:
java.io.IOException - if the output buffer raises this exception on append()

chop

public static char[] chop(char[] s,
                          int p,
                          int l,
                          char c)
Cuts a segment of a char array at the first occurrence of a delimiter.

Parameters:
s - a char array containing the segment
p - the position in the array of the first character of the segment
l - the length of (number of characters in) the segment
c - the delimiter character
Returns:
a copy of the initial portion of the segment, ending at the first Occurrence of the delimiter, or a copy of the whole segment if the delimiter does not occur

split

public static char[][] split(char[] s,
                             int p,
                             int l,
                             char c,
                             int n)
Splits a segment of a char array into fields, at occurrences of a delimiter.

Parameters:
s - a char array containing the segment
p - the position in the array of the first character of the segment
l - the length of (number of characters in) the segment
c - the delimiter character
n - the maximum number of fields to extract
Returns:
an array containing at most n elements, which are the portions of the segment between occurrences of the delimiter. If there are more than n of those, the last element of the array contains the remaining characters of the segment after the n-th occurrence of the delimiter.

split

public static char[][] split(char[] s,
                             char c,
                             int n)
Splits a char array into fields, at occurrences of a delimiter.

Parameters:
s - a char array
c - the delimiter character
n - the maximum number of fields to extract
Returns:
an array containing at most n elements, which are the portions of the char array between occurrences of the delimiter. If there are more than n of those, the last element of the array contains the remaining characters of the array after the n-th occurrence of the delimiter.

split

public static java.lang.CharSequence[] split(java.lang.CharSequence s,
                                             char c,
                                             int n)
Splits a character sequence into fields, at occurrences of a delimiter.

Parameters:
s - a character sequence
c - the delimiter character
n - the maximum number of fields to extract
Returns:
an array containing at most n elements, which are the portions of the argument character sequence between occurrences of the delimiter. If there are more than n of those, the last element of the array contains the remaining of the character sequence after the n-th occurrence of the delimiter.

split

public static java.lang.String[] split(java.lang.String s,
                                       char c,
                                       int n)
Splits a string into fields, at occurrences of a delimiter.

Parameters:
s - a string
c - the delimiter character
n - the maximum number of fields to extract
Returns:
an array containing at most n elements, which are the portions of the argument string between occurrences of the delimiter. If there are more than n of those, the last element of the array contains the remaining of the string after the n-th occurrence of the delimiter.

splitCmd

public static java.lang.String[] splitCmd(java.lang.String s)
Splits a string into "command-line" fields.

The string is cut in separate substrings at every white-space, except when those spaces are escaped, or are contained within literal sequences.

"Escaped" characters, i.e. characters prefixed by an (unescaped) '\' backslash character, are "unescaped" (the backslash is removed).

"Literal" sequences are sequences starting and ending with the same (unescaped) delimiter (one of '\'' or '\"'), in which all occurrences of that same delimiter are escaped.

Parameters:
s - the String containing the concatenated fields
Returns:
an array containing the command-line fields

format

public static void format(java.lang.Appendable buf,
                          java.lang.CharSequence fmt,
                          java.lang.Object... var)
                   throws java.io.IOException
Formats a character sequence and a variadic array of arguments into a buffer.

All characters from the format are added to the buffer, except those within an escape sequence. Escape sequences start with a '%' character, can specify several optional parameters, and end with a format type character. Each escape sequence consumes one argument from the array, and transforms that argument into a format item, appended to the buffer, according to the type and parameters of the escape sequence.

Accepted format types are:

  • '%': outputs a literal '%' character, without consuming an argument
  • 'c': formats the argument (which must be of type Character) as a single character
  • 's': formats the argument (which must be of type CharSequence) as a character sequence
  • 'S': formats the argument (which must be null, or of type CharSequence) as a character sequence, outputting "null" if it is null
  • 'd': formats the argument (which must be of type Number) as a signed decimal integer
  • 'u': formats the argument (which must be of type Number) as an unsigned decimal integer
  • 'x': formats the argument (which must be of type Number) as an hexadecimal integer, using lower case letters
  • 'X': formats the argument (which must be of type Number) as an hexadecimal integer, using upper case letters
All other format types result in the argument being converted to a String using Object.toString(), and the result being formatted as though an 'S' format had been specified.

Parameters in order, any of the optional following:

  • '<' or '>': an orientation specifier, defining the alignment direction of the formatting: respectively left, or right (default: right)
  • '|': a flag indicating that if the formatting results in more characters than the specified size, it should be truncated (default: none)
  • '+' or '-': specifies that signed formatting of a positive number should respectively include or omit a leading '+' character (default: omit)
  • a decimal integer indicating the size (number of characters) of the formatted result
  • '.' (a dot) followed by a decimal integer indicating:
    • for unsigned decimal integers: the radix (default: 10),
    • for hexadecimal integers: the shift (the number of bits that each digit represents, i.e. the base-2 logarithm of the radix)

Parameters:
buf - the output buffer
fmt - the format defining how the arguments should be written to the buffer
var - the variadic array of arguments
Throws:
java.io.IOException - if appending to the buffer produced an I/O error
